item.description: Simple roll and move game based on cartoon show from the times. The Rocky and Bullwinkle Show featured Rocket "Rocky" J. Squirrel, a flying squirrel, and his best friend Bullwinkle J. Moose, a dim-witted but good-natured moose who both lived in Frostbite Falls, Minnesota. The scheming villains in most episodes were the fiendish, but inept, agents of the fictitious nation of Pottsylvania: Boris Badenov and Natasha Fatale.

link.value: TV Series: The Rocky and Bullwinkle Show

item.description:
Wehrschach, also called Tak-Tik, was published by the nationalsocialist German magazine "Die Wehrmacht" in 1937/1938. It brought modern pieces to a Chess-like board: Infantry, Armor, Fighter and Bomber planes, Artillery, and a unique piece (the 'Hauptfigur'), styled like an eagle, which abstractly represented the government, industrial base, and morale of the state.

On an Board with 11 x 11 squares you play a chess-like game with 18 pieces per player, for instance the "Jagdflieger" or the "Panzerkampfwagen", all 3D and of Bakelite. These can move only vertical or horizontal, but a different number of squares, with the exception of the "Panzerkampfwagen", which might also move like the knight in chess, but without jumping over other pieces.

To capture an enemy piece you need to threaten it with two of your pieces instead of just one.

The board is divided through diagonal lines (the main road and the river) and two more lines crossing the 3rd and 9th row indicating walls and two lake tiles which block all movement except for the planes.

Gameplay was more or less like chess, but with some special rules for the different figures. There were several ways to win: capture of the Hauptfigur; destruction of all enemy Infantry; reduction of his fighting power; occupation of his homeland; etc. This, coupled with the two-to-one capture rules makes it more challenging (and rewarding!) than Chess.

item.description:
Word-O-Matic "The Competitive Word Building Game"

From the Box-

"Race Against Time...Develop More Words Than Your Opponents."

"Challenge Yourself...Challenge Others."

"Different Letter Combination With Every Spin of WORD-O-MATIC."

You pull the handle on the word-o-matic machine (requires 1 "C" battery) and the wheels start moving. You then hit the 5 buttons on the front of the word-o-matic to stop the wheels. You have until the sand timer runs out to make as many 4 - 7 letter words as you can.
Fill in the missing words in wacky stories using only the letters from key words...

The object of this game is to be the first player to arrive back in the garden with a present from the Snowman Party. Before you can do this, you'll have to complete the rest of his costume by collecting 4 cards that represent the building of the Snowman - the body, the head, the face and the scarf plus hat.
Contents:

Instruction Sheet

16x Building Cards with 4x cards in each set of body, head, face, hat and scarf

4x Present Cards

Dice and Shaker

4x Snowmen Pieces

Counters

Deluxe Playing Board

What's That Song is a lively and entertaining game, featuring over 700 song titles, for two or more players or teams. Spin the needle to determine the decade. Select a song title from that decade 50s 60s 70s 80s or old faves and sing a clue from the song title. Singing, facial expressions and body movements are all encouraged to help your team guess the song title. Points are awarded for the correct answer.
A collection of four games in one with a Strawberry Shortcake theme: Memory, Lotto, Dominoes, and Bingo.
This is a game used to help kids build their self-esteem. Developed by a PhD in kids psychology.

You bid cards and play similarly to a trump style game. the high trump card overrides all others and takes the trick. that is until the Shift card is played, then the low trump takes the trick. Timing the shift to the low trump is key to winning.

Rukshuk - the world's original game of rock-balancing is back with more edge-of-the-seat fun!

RUKSHUK - Edition 2 features all new Game Rocks and cool new RUKSHUK formations guaranteed to challenge and thrill!

Race against the clock to build the different Rukshuk formations and score as many points as you can. Skill, luck and strategy determine who will score the most points and win!

1 to 5 players draw 7 game rocks each then turn over a card to reveal a RUKSHUK formation. Regular and bonus points are scored by building as much of the formation as possible within the time limit. If a formation topples, it must be rebuilt before time runs out! Points are scored for the balanced rocks at the end of the time limit, with additional points for three-of-a-kind and completion. Choose to play some or all formations in a game, and the player with the highest points wins.

Re-implements:

 Rukshuk

This is a simple game of loading semi-trucks... players each have a truck "frame" in which they place pieces (rectangles & squares) based on the roll of two dice. Certain types of pieces can not be immediately placed but are stored to the side, waiting for the right "hole" in the back of your truck. The first player to fill their truck wins; if the pieces run out without any player filling their truck, the player with the least empty space wins.

Ages 6-12

item.description:
From the publisher:

The quick thinking 'Electronic' name game. Be the first to hit the button, and say a name that fits the card and letter. The fastest player keeps the card and the most cards wins the game! Includes one electronic unit with lights and sounds and 30 cards.

As far as I know this is the only set of miniatures rules specifically dealing with air-to-air combat between helicopters, though air-to-ground and ground-to-air combat is also covered. The rules are intended for use with 1/300th scale miniatures and the other game scales are as follows:

1 model = 1 aircraft, vehicle, infantry platoon
1 turn = 10-15 seconds
1" = 100 yards

Each turn the player picks the speed and altitude for each helicopter they control, which determines how far they will move, how much they may turn and their chance of crashing into the ground, if flying too fast and too low. Combat is resolved using the usual die rolls and tables, with the different makes of helicopter being able to take different amounts of damage before they are eliminated.

The majority of the rule book is taken up with the helicopter data sheets and there are no less than 46 of them. Ground elements are detailed generically. There are also five sample scenarios.

item.description:
Sharpen your pencils - and your intuition - for this quick playing "think-in-sync" party game. Draw a category card and in 45 seconds, list as many related words that come to mind. When the timer runs out, roll the die - if it lands on HIT, pick a word that you think everyone wrote; if it lands on MISS, pick one that only you wrote. Choose wisely and score big points. The player with the highest score wins. Hit or Miss - the cant MISS game that will turn your next party into a HIT!

2007 Mensa Select

item.description:
From the Publisher:
A Superhero themed math based standalone card game for ages 8 and up.

Villains lurk in the streets of Infinity City and the only hope is the Numbers League. Assemble your team of Superheroes, use the sum of their incredible powers and ingenious devices to capture as many villains as you can.

Numbers League - Adventures in Addiplication is a stand alone superhero themed card game where your basic math skills can save the day. The more you play the sharper these skills will become until no villain is safe from your numerical onslaught.

Included in the box are 24 double-sided Villain cards (different values on each side), 21 Device cards, 75 Superhero body part cards (25 heads, 25 chests, and 25 legs), four note pads and a 16-page full-color rules booklet with instructions in English, German, French, and Spanish.

Note
The current printing comes in a much smaller box, omitting the note pads and replacing the rule book with an English-only full-color trifold.

item.description:
From the Publisher's website:

Test your math and strategy skills against the luck of the roll. Simply roll the dice and add or multiply the numbers. Then claim a space on the number board. First player to connect four in a row wins. Learning math has never been such a fun challenge for both kids AND adults! Ages 6 & up.

From the Publisher's website:

Its the game where you get to express all kinds of feelings by drawing, charading and talking. Can you draw the word confused? Or act out the word sneaky? Can you say the tongue twister Peter Piper and make other people guess the word forgetful? Every correct guess you move ahead a space in the race to the finish.

Tactex is a hexagonal version of Piet Hein's classic TacTix which was a two-dimensional generalization of Nim. In Tac Tix, players take turns removing pieces away from a rectangular grid. In Tactex, pieces are placed on a five by five by five hexagonally-tiled field and are removed from one of the nine vertical columns or eighteen diagonal rows.

item.description:
You have to crack the safe codes by throwing dice to earn victory points. Each safe card is worth 2 through 5 points. The player with the most points at the end of the game wins.

When it is your turn you throw all 5 dice. You have to put at least one dice aside. The pips of this dice tell you on which number you can put a marker on one of the three revealed safe cards.

Now you have to decide to stop or go on. If you go on you throw the remaining dice and have to put at least another dice aside and so a counter on a safe card. 
If you stop you can take a safe card on which all code numbers are covered by markers.

If you throw only pits that are not on a revealed safe card your turn ends immediately and you get no safe card.

Re-themed by:

 IGOR: The Monster Making Game

item.description: The game of Ximo is a set of variants of the traditional game Nim, where you try to be the last player able to pick a marker up off the table. It comes with a cloth bag and a supply of wooden disks with various symbols on them. The symbols place restrictions on what disks may be picked up, allowing for strategic plays. There are several variations included.

From the game package:
How will you do in the line of fire?
Seek and destroy your opponent's ships in this all-out, no holds barred dice duel. Secretly set up your tokens on your battlefield and brace yourself as your opponent attacks. Was it a hit or miss? Fire back and see if you can be the first player to sink all of your opponent's ships, and win!

From Erik Arneson's website:
Players first play tokens (numbered 3 to 11) on each of their five ships, making sure to put them in order from lowest to highest -- although duplicate numbers are allowed. To attack, each player rolls three dice and chooses two. They place those two dice next to a token, and if the total equals the value of the token, a hit is scored. Rolls of 2 and 12 are always hits. Unfortunately, this clever Battleship-based dice game is not very easy to find. Your best bet is to look in drug stores and grocery stores.

Multilingo can be played in English, French, Italian or Spanish ­ or in any combination of the four. Players spell words using letter tiles. The game gets kicked up several notches as players "borrow" other players' words to create new ones. Ingenuity, a keen eye and an array of techniques are used to create and recreate words. Will you be borrowing the most valuable words? Handicap levels the field so that anyone can play, even sophisticated word-smiths can play with children just learning to read.

Designed in conjunction with the Girl Guides Association.

"Part of the fun of being in the Brownie organization is trying to collect badges by achieving efficiency in a number of categories. The object of this game is just the same. Players have to collect interest badges by successfully answering questions on the subjects chosen."

Players try to collect five badges and be the first to collect the trefoil badge. Players roll a dice to move around the board. Upon landing on an interest badge space, they must choose one of the tiles from a face down selection. Most of the tiles represent Brownie badges in several categories, a few are hazardous events, and one shows the trefoil, crucial to winning the game. To collect a badge of the revealed category, the player must answer a trivia question relating to the category. Badges are available in the following categories:

Animal Lover; Artist; Book Lover; Brownie Friendship; Cook; Collector; Conservation; Craft; Discoverer; First Aid; House Orderly; Music Lover; Pony Rider; Rambler; Safety in the Home.

If the question is answered correctly, the badge tile is placed on the player's arm card (representing the badge being sewn onto the player's shirt sleeve). If it is answered incorrectly, the tile is turned face down again. When a player has collected five badges on her arm card, she must try to find the Trefoil badge from the face down selection in order to win the game.

Players can steal badges from Brownies who trespass on another player's campsite. Bonus badges can be won by landing on toadstool spaces and answering a general knowledge question. The game can end prematurely if too many Brown Owl spaces are landed on.

item.description:
CLASSIC STATIS PRO BASEBALL is an authentic game based on statistics of every major league player. Each player should perform in this game just as he does in real life; only your ability as manager will determine the outcome of every game.

CLASS STATIS PRO BASEBALL is a no-frills version of the award-winning Statis Pro Baseball games... no frills because you do not get a playing board or score pad. You don't really need these components because it is an easy matter to keep track of base runners and score on a plain sheet of paper.

You DO get two dice (white and colored) and Player Cards representing every major league player of significance for the previous season. You must cut each card apart along the dotted line, then collate by team.

Each Classic baseball team contains 25 players, 15 fielders and 10 pitchers, and 2 pitcher at-bat cards that are standard for all teams; including American League teams - the cards being used when involved in either World Series or inter-league play, if you so desire.

Summary of Rules (from Instructions)

Gauntlet is a role-playing board game in which players (often referred to in their game role as Travelers) battle their way through a maze of hazardous tunnels and monsters.

Gauntlet may be played in four different versions: the Race Game, the Treasure Game, the Hunter Game, or the Tournament Game. The object in each is to be the first player to have his or her traveler cross from one side of the board to the other. When one player does, on the following turn the Gauntlet will begin to collapse, starting with the innermost square and proceeding outward by "rings" with each turn until the entire board has collapsed. If no other players make it across the Gauntlet before the entire board has fallen, the first player wins the game. If any other player makes it across to tie the first player, the tied player who has accumulated the most points wins the game.

An old game from the series "Fridolin-Spiele in der Tüte", cheap games in a paper bag instead of a box.

Obviously (there are board, dice and small airplanes in it) it`s a dice-rolling game for children, where each player has to move his airplane one round through the sky (its subtitle is: "Ein Wettfliegen durch die Sternenwelt", so it`s a race-game).

Simple game something like a pin ball machine. Ball is hit and goes into holes that represent hits, balls, strikes and outs. When that happens players move around the bases. Object is to score more runs than your opponent. Game comes with base runners for both the red and the blue teams.

Guess the meaning of an acronym or abbreviation to advance around a board. First person/team to the end that answers a question correctly wins. About 20 categories of cards, randomly distributed. Right answers without hints allow you to roll on a 4-5-6 die, while needing a hint allows only the 1-2-3 die.

The main difference between this edition and the regular edition of Pictionary is the "Challenge Die". The Challenge Die may be used at the start of your turn to change the way you must draw. These special dice components can make you:
- Draw 2 pictures in less than 1 minute.
- Draw with your eyes closed.
- Draw a picture using only one line (don't lift your pencil).
- Draw with your 'off hand' (righties use their left hand, and vice versa).
- Play with the regular rules

A nice change of pace for those who like this classic drawing game.

The preparation of the game is limited to the allocation of the characters and the placement of tokens clue.
The characters represented are 6, Sherlock Holmes, Watson, Lestrade, Moriarty, Hudson and the couple Todd and Smiley, that those who remember the cartoon certainly recognize, and each have two cards, so you could find with two players represent the same character.

The course, as befits a children's play is very simple, and everyone in their turn will only turn the "roulette" and see which of the nine squares of the board will go to search for clues. Seven of these boxes are red and starting the game with three tokens clue places on them, a blue box used to have the 21 coins in excess, and the yellow box is the "waste".

When a player comes in a red box, to check whether one of the tokens present there is one depicting one of its special character, in which case he must take it and place it face down in front of him. If it finds the first token must then catch the blue box and keep it the same way ahead in case corresponds to their character, or discard it in the yellow box otherwise.

The game continues, until it is emptied a red box or blue box.
Then the player who drew the last coin, discovered the chips has previously collected (if it has, otherwise you go to the next player) and becomes the examination. The other at this point watching the chips and consulting support control, they must understand what the character looked, and as said before, who first guesses wins the game. If anyone guess, the player who collected more tokens, and in this case is virtually impossible to win the examiner, because even if he had collected a lot of chips, surely the many tokens collected would go to "unmask".

There are two main differences between this edition and the regular edition of Pictionary: the "Challenge die" and "Fun phrase" cards.

The Challenge die is rolled at the start of each turn to change the way players must draw. The possible challenges are:
- Draw 2 pictures in less than 1 minute.
- Draw with your eyes closed.
- Draw a picture using only one line (you cannot lift your pencil).
- Draw with your 'off hand' (righties use their left hand, and vice versa).
- Play with the regular rules

The Fun phrase cards have common phrases on them, but are more challenging to draw. On any turn, the Picturist (the person drawing) may choose to play one of the Fun Phrase cards instead of the regular cards. If the team guesses correctly, they may add two points to their next roll of the standard die.

A nice change of pace for those who like this classic drawing game.

name.value: Talismán: El Juego de la Búsqueda Mágica
Talisman: Il Gioco delle Avventure Magiche
Talisman: Le jeu des quêtes magiques (4ème édition révisée)
Talisman: O Mágico Jogo de Aventura
タリスマン 基本セット 第４版改訂版 日本語版

item.description:
Theme:

Talisman is an adventure board game set in a high fantasy medieval world. Players have 14 characters to choose from all based on role playing archetypes, such as heroes, wizards, villains, thieves, monsters, etc. The game makes players feel they are traveling the world to find equipment, weapons, ancient relics, and companions that will help them on their quest to acquire the Crown of Command. Along the way they visit various locales in the worlds, battle each other and fantastic creatures to make their way to the top.

Goal:

Each player is trying to move from the outer world and ultimately to the inner world. Players wander the outer, middle, and inner worlds trying to acquire equipment, weapons, and companions. They will also improve statistics with equipment, companions, and encounters and battles with fantasy creatures and each other. Once they complete a Talisman quest, players will enter the inner world and face its challenges to finally reach the Portal of Power to claim the Crown of Command. Then the other players must race to stop this player before he eventually kills them all with the Command spell.

Gameplay:

To begin, players select a character card from among the 14 provided. Characters have basic statistics to start. These are Life [hit points], Strength [physical prowess], and Craft [Magic and Intelligence]. Some characters are naturally more gifted in combat and others in magic, while others are mix of the two. Additionally characters are often differentiated with unique abilities, starting equipment, and starting spells. This all makes the players actually feel different during play. In addition items and companions players acquire during play also add to statistics, increasing Strength, Craft, Life or adding new abilities, etc.

Actual game play is relatively simple, making the game easy to pick up with novices. On a player's turn they throw a die for movement. Player then chooses which direction, left or right, or if meeting qualifications may be able to move from outer to middle world, or middle to inner world. Once on space, player follows instructions on space, or encounters face up cards already in space, or other player if in space. Most spaces have a player draw a number of cards to encounter. These can be creatures, companions, weapons, equipment, treasure, or relics. Players must fight creatures and win before acquiring any other items or companions. If another player is in the space, players may attack with either Craft or Strength but are not required to do so. The defender defends with same statistic attacked with. If the defender loses, he loses a life and an item or companion of attackers choice. If the attacker loses, he loses a life.

Players start in the outer world, and build up their character's statistics and items to try and move to the middle world. There are two ways to move up to the middle world, one requiring a test of strength and the other a boat man's ride for a price. Once in the middle world, play proceeds in the same manner, but the challenge generally is increased with more threats such as the desert and temple. However, there is more potential for encounters and items as most spaces now draw more than one card.

In the middle world, players may also acquire a Talisman quest, that once completed, will grant them a Talisman. The Talisman is required to unlock the Crown of Command and pass through the Portal of Power in the Inner World.

Once players have a Talisman and have enough Strength or Craft to enter the Portal of Power, they will try to enter the Inner World. There they must face and survive the guardians there, like the Vampire's Tower and Werewolf before claiming the Crown of Command. Once a player claims the Crown of Command, they can cast the Command Spell, automatically forcing a player to lose a life. It then becomes a race for the Crown as the other players try to take the player with the Crown down before he finishes them all off.

Revised using:

 Talisman: Upgrade Pack

item.description:
Agilidade ... a 3-in-row game.

Material: glass game board, black and white wood playing pieces - 7 per player.

White starts and, in turn, pieces are placed on any one of 5 spaces, including on other pieces.
The object is to get 3 same-color pieces in a row - horizontally, vertically or diagonally.

Based on the animated film, players are robots moving around Robot City (the board) collecting spare parts tokens. Watch out for The Sweeper - he's a wind-up robot who runs in a grooved track in the board - if he touches you, you lose a token & go back to the last station.

A plastic dome covers an "arena" where energy balls are dispensed by a wind-up gizmo. Players use pinball-like flippers to keep energy balls from ending up in their scoring tray. (Gates are included with the game so that you can play with 2-4 players, even though there are four stations.)

"I was a Book of Mormon prophet who raised the Title of Liberty. Who Am I? I gathered the songs for the first hymnbook of the Church. Who Am I? I told people that a flood would cover the earth if they didn’t repent. Who Am I? Do you know the answers? If you do, raise your hand. If you don’t, you soon will with this fun new game for the whole family.
Four Games in One! Younger children will love playing the “Match Game.” Older kids will have fun with the “Fill in the Blank” or “Who Am I” games. Even adults can get in on the fun by acting out the answers in the “Guess Who I Am” game. No matter who you are, you’ll just love playing Who Am I?"

This unusual take on Snap or Pairs takes place in the bath 
Contents include; 25 waterproof playing cards, with 5 different fish character designs. Cut out models of the 5 fishy characters to float around and catch when a match is made 
Also includes a fishing net to dry the cards

Divide the waterproof playing cards between the players and float the 5 fish characters around in the tub. Proceed to play as you would do in 'snap'. When a match is made the first player to grab the matching floating fish (which will be swimming around the players) wins the pack of cards.

Ages 4+

name.value: The Lord of the Rings Board Game

item.description:
The Lord of the Rings Board Game is a roll and move parody board game for fans of Lord of the Rings, not to be mistaken for the Reiner Knizia game (or any of the many other Lord of the Rings games).

Players have six tasks from the book that they strive to accomplish (on their handy "Things to Do" check sheets). Players begin in Rivendell, visit Moria, Edoras, Isengard, Erech, Pelargir, Minas Tirith and Mount Doom to complete their tasks, then return to the Shire. Each task requires a successful die roll to complete and players draw "Plot Complication" cards that can make things easier, harder or much harder. Along the way, there are other locations that require players to draw plot complications.

The game is freely available on the Tolkien Sarcasm website (http://flyingmoose.org/tolksarc/tolksarc.htm), a Tolkien humor website. It has its own special page: http://flyingmoose.org/tolksarc/boardgame/lotrgame.htm. To create the game, a fair amount of publishing work is required, as the cards and board are not presented in printer-ready form.

Home Page: http://flyingmoose.org/tolksarc/boardgame/lotrgame.htm

item.description:
This wargame involves a (so far) hypothetical Australian invasion of Fiji in response to a hypothetical coup by the Fijian military in December 2006.

This game can be downloaded from http://www.mikekreuzer.com/dtp.htm

Components
1 map
27 counters
21 markers 
1 7-page rulebook

Player must supply 2 six sided dice.

Tack™ is a deck of playing cards and a game authoring system. 14+ different games have be designed with this system. There are three games included. The publisher encourages people to invent games that meld numbers, colors, symbols or other combination. Each card has six Types in a simple and functional face. These playing cards also have many melding opportunities and some of the best melds use addition or subtraction as the goal for collection.

The Tack™ deck is suitable for playing new games unavailable to a regular card deck. Regular card games including Crazy Eights, Oh Hell!, Texas Hold 'Em, Poker, Hearts can be played with this deck.

Each tuck-box has rules for three original games ( http://www.gameyex.com/rules.html ) and comes complete with all the tools needed to author new games.

The quality of this deck is good and feels best after it has been worked a few times. Printed on 14pt German card stock with a glossy finish, it pleases both the eye and the mind.

Online Play

 http://www.gameyex.com/games.html (against AI)

Licensed Traveller Game. This stand-alone game is a miniatures wargame, a board game, and also a supplemental combat system for use with the various Traveller Roleplaying Games.

From the BITS Website (www.bits.org.uk):
At Close Quarters 
ACQ has a tactical system that emphasizes the action and reaction process of real combat. Cautious combatants with fast reactions who use all their available cover will out-live reckless gun-slinger types! ACQ adds excitement to critical combat situations within your Traveller game, and is also excellent for ground skirmishes and starship boarding actions.

Comprehensive rules are included for ranged combat (from aimed shots to suppression fire), melee combat, movement, action/reaction situations, types of cover (and how to reach it quickly), damage effects and healing, zero-G combat and much more. It includes extensive weapons lists and a quick-reference booklet for all the key tables, tasks and actions. And Penguins.

ISBN 1-901228-13-4, 48 pages, A5 format, written by Doug Berry & James Lindsay. © 2000. No Penguins were harmed in the creation of ACQ, but it is the Traveller book that introduced them to the game!

This boardgame is based on the PC-game Backpacker.
For 2-4 players or you can play in teams.

The players are going to visit cities around the world, and they decide how many before the game starts. (for a beginner it's best to start with 3 cities)
Every city has its own board. The players arrive in the city and they try to earn some money by answering questions about different occupations. They also get money if they can answer questions related to the city. These may be about history, politics, geography etc.

Knowledge is money. And the player/team with the most money after a city is finished gets a postcard from that city. The first player/team to get 3 postcards wins the game.

SPEAK LOVE MAKE LOVE is a two-sided game board. The fully opened side is the Speak Love part. When you fold over either half of the upper board the Make Love side of the board comes to play. In addition, the game has a right playing side and a left side. In the game when it's your turn you are the active player and your partner is the passive. In many cases the game requires working together to play an activity. The more cooperative and open you are, the more fun, discovery and experimentation is available.

item.description:
Chess on a 9x9 Board using 36 pieces instead of the standard 32. The 9x9 board is symmetrical, unlike the asymmetrical standard chess board. Each players gets 1 additional pawn and 2 "Ministers" which replace the Queen and move in the same manner as the Queen.

Shares some similarities to Modern Chess.

Triball is a three player, three dimensional version of tic-tac-toe (naughts and crosses). An acrylic shell serves as the base and multi-colored balls are dropped into the grid of nine columns. The goal is simple, be the first to get three of your balls in a row.

Visit http://www.triball.co.uk for more information about this game or play an online demo there.

Variant on Pachisi, with some extra stuff, including partnership.

From intro at start of rules:
Ollie, Wally, Carlie and Holly are four contractors desperate for work for their squads. There's a big contract up for grabs and it goes to the first team on site. The contract is too big for one squad and so Ollie has tams up with Wally and Carlie has teamed up with Holly.

Times are hard and Ollie, Wally, Carlie and Holly will stoop to any kind of underhand skulduggery, obstructing and back stabbing to get the job.

A memory based card placement game. All cards are placed face down on the table beside the board. Turn and pick correct card for placement in order building sentences. If wrong color is drawn, the card is returned face down and the turn passes to next player.

Swedish version.

21E is co-operative game of following the clues and finding the jewels. The game is played by deciphering the clues sent from Dr. Iverson. The E21 code uses symbols to represent syllables. Once the clue is decoded you are on to the next city and clue. As the game progresses variants are added to the 21E code to make harder for you and the thieves to decipher the clues. The game includes a Code Cracker card, a deck of Code Cards, one set of city clue cards, paper and pen, and a Mission Pack.

This game is a limited edition re-creation of the fantasy based game "Dragon Quest Dungeon" circa 1990.

There are three ways to play the game, each with increasingly more depth in the rules.

The basic game has each player secretly set up his own dungeon with a stand-up cut-out castle between the two players to shield the other from viewing his opponent's dungeon. Each player has 24 square shaped walls that can be placed throughout the dungeon to block the other player from reaching the Dragon Lord. At the beginning of the game, the players share the starting location and the location of the DragonLord in their respective dungeons.

The game play mechanics are very similar to "Battleship" in that the dungeon is laid out in a grid (rows and columns) and each player takes turns shouting out a location in the grid which will reveal a clear path or a wall. The winner is the first player to successfully navigate to the DragonLord of their opponent's dungeon.

The advanced rules include monster pieces; treasure chests, combat, and cards with text on them that make the game play more immersive.

item.description: This is Scrabble (and made by the same company) with a "Where's Wally?" overlay. Each player has their own foolscap-sized Where's Wally? picture (double-sided for 8 unique pictures). When forming words, all normal Scrabble rules and bonuses apply AS WELL AS scoring double if the word you spell can be recognized in your picture. You get a bonus 100 points for spelling (and finding) Wally.

You place 8 of your 10 stones alternately on a field of the board of your choice, not on the border.
In the game you take a Trihop with one of your stones to move it around.
The destination of the game is to place all 8 of my stones in my own destination-area on the border.

The Clemens Gerhards version of this includes Zoom.

Your goal: Place four of your tokens in a perfect square at any position in the 6x6 inner board area.

Your tools: The aforementioned tokens and the movement of same.

In Zoom, each player has a number of tokens that start on the perimeter of a 6×6 playing area. On a turn, you can move one of your tokens along free positions of the perimeter area (not jumping over any tokens) from any reachable edge position of the board horizontally or vertically and you must continue movement in straight line inward, stopping whenever you choose; alternatively you move an own token along a straight line from inside the 6x6 playing area to another inner 6x6 board position; you may not jump over previously placed tokens, whether yours or the opponent's. The first player to create a perfect square of his own tokens wins.

The Clemens Gerhards edition rules neither state anything about size of the perfect square to build (2x2, 3x3, ..., 6x6) nor state anything about it's bearing (orthogonally, diagonally, or oblique). Sometimes players seem to assume or to interpret the rules that perfect squares are only valid and allowed of size 2x2 in orthogonally bearing (changing the game play enormously this way!).

item.description: This is a mechanical baseball game. The players sit on opposite sides of the game. The batter locks their side of the spring-loaded spinner then the pitcher locks theirs. The pitcher secretly moves a slider either left or right. Then the pitcher pitches by pulling their unlock switch. The batter than has to hit the ball by pulling their unlock switch. After this is done the result shows through either the left or right window in the game field. This is repeated until there are three outs and then the game is turned around as the sides are switched. There are dials to show the current count, outs and score.

Here is the ultimate in Realism for everyone old enough to know Baseball. All the action and suspense of the Real Game! Definitely not a mechanical toy. Special Team Slides dramatize the Duel between Pitcher and Batter. 30 colorful Players equal the very best, in Major League Performance. Illuminated Play-Viewer shows the Play at every Base . . . Hits, Runs, Outs, Bunts and Base-Stealing . . . All the limitless Variations of Play that distinguish our National Game!

The starter booklet provides an excellent entry-point into the world of fantasy battles. New players will find easy to follow examples for all the main parts of the Warhammer game, as well as profiles for all the models in the box. The 144-page pocket-sized rulebook is a useful resource for all hobbyists. All the information you need to play the game is right here. This boxed game contains over 100 Citadel Miniatures, a pocket-sized rulebook, starter booklet, dice, templates and scenery."

Reimplements

link.value: Warhammer: The Game of Fantasy Battles (7th Edition)

item.description:
This is a game of tactical space combat, with each counter representing a single ship. It includes a ship design system, and a set of pre-designed ships.

In flavor, it seems to feel somewhere between a slightly more complex Starfire and a simplified Star Fleet Battles.

The name of the game is derived from the fairy-tale Sleeping Beauty ("Dornröschen" in German) which is well known in many parts of Europe, including Germany and Russia. Although the game may appear superficially as a variant of Anglo-American Checkers, it has many unusual features that are not known in any other Checkers game:


 Men capture adjacent enemy ladies (the equivalent of kings in Checkers) by the short leap backwards, but never forwards. However, adjacent enemy men are captured by them in the usual way by leaping forwards.



 If a man reaches the opponent's back rank, he is promoted to a sleeping beauty (and turned upside down), if the player has already a lady. A player can never have two or more ladies at the same time. Sleeping beauties are inactive until they are woken up.



 A lady captures by the short leap like the king in English Draughts / American Straight Checker. A lady can also capture in the Chess way by replacement like a Ferz in Shatranj, not just by jumping.



 It is not permitted to combine both ways of capturing in one move.



 Capturing by replacement is not compulsory, whereas capturing by jumping is and the greatest number possible must be captured. Consequently, jumping always takes precedence over replacement, unless a lady can capture the opponent's lady. Then the lady that captures has the choice between both ways of capturing, which is called Royal Privilege



 A sleeping beauty may not move or capture, nor may she be captured. 



 After a sleeping beauty is woken up, she is permitted to make a "jump of joy", a rule that was was inspired by the Kurierspiel. However, a jump of joy is only permitted if the square crossed over is (1) vacant and (2) not "threatened" (or "guarded" in Chess terminology).



 The object of the game is to leave the opponent without a valid move, either by capturing all his pieces, or by blocking them completely.



 A game can never end in a draw, thus "vanquishing the curse of the Checkers draw" as Kerry Handscomb, the editor of the Abstract Games magazine put it. There are, however, rare positions very similar to jishogi, or impasse in Japanese Chess that need a special rule: In a continous sequence of moves in which only ladies are moved, a particular lady is not permitted to move onto the same square twice after the full board position has been repeated once (even if the lady occupied this square before the position was repeated).



 A point scoring system is used to determine the margin of win. The winner gets as many points as there are still pieces on the board (of any kind and color). The loser gets zero points, even if he has still pieces left (in the case of a blockade).


The game has been extensively covered in the Abstract Games magazine whose Canadian editors described it as "fascinating" and "rather strange".

item.description:
Welcome to Gods & Minions – the customizable card game of fantasy warfare

First of all: Gods & Minions is a card based tactical combat game, so one game represents one battle. You and your opponent each represent generals who command their troops. The troops are displayed using cards. Compared to a full wargame (like Warhammer), Gods & Minions is much lighter on the rules and compared to a customizable card game (like Legend of the five Rings), Gods & Minions focus is 100% on the battles (instead of kingdom building, diplomacy or intrigue).

Join the godswar in this action loaded, customizable and collectible card game. Assemble your army from a huge variety of nations and factions available. Collect and play gods, minions, enhance your troops with artefacts & equipment and unleash powerful spells, command mighty beasts, towering war-machines and unique personalities. Fight for dominance over a fantasy world broken by age old war of nations. Be part of a universe where almighty gods are pulling the strings behind from the scenes and decide between life and death as they see fit. Be prepared when this brand new fantasy wargame hits the shelves!

Unique Features:


 Full-fledged and affordable tabletop warfare system without expensive miniatures
 Manaless resource system without staple cards that clutter your deck
 No artificial rarities – you get exactly the cards and amount of copies you want
 Lightweight wargame rules prevent slow gameplay without being over simplified
 All rules and cards available for download. for free. always.
 You pay only if you want a printed copy (physical product) of your own.
 No dice: Gods & Minions does not require any additonal component or luck factor!
 No Grid & No Rulers: An innovative movement system renders rulers obsolete.
 No shallow story: Dive into a background world full of history and folklore.
 Welcome to the end times – welcome to the world of Gods & Minions!

Korsoun 1944 covers the Korsun-Cherkassy pocket, in which two German army corps were encircled by the Soviets in January-February 1944. One player controls the Soviets and tries to close the pocket, while the other one controls the Germans.

Published in Vae Victis magazine #72 (Jan-Feb 2007 issue).

Components include:
- the magazine including wargaming & historical articles, plus the Rules in French;
- One A2 size colour mapsheet (41.5 x 59 cm; 16 x 23 inches);
- Two thin cardboard NON-die-cut countersheets, one for the front side, one for the back side, which need to be cut out and stuck together.

English translations of the Rules, the Tables and the accompanying article describing the battle of the Korsun Pocket are available from Grognard.com, and (for the Rules) maybe also from the Vae Victis website.

item.description:
From the company's web site:

Six Nations must solve internal affairs without creating conflicts within their own borders.

As the game progresses, hot spots could develop — and by game’s end several or all of the Nations could be at war. The game is then lost.

Each Nation creates a balanced territory so that a balanced world results in which population does not exceed land and resources and work is available for everyone. On the religious, cultural and political side, all sectors are also in balance with no particular sector dominating another. The key to achieving this balance is Right Education, in which intelligence and compassion are nurtured. How well the players use Right Education and deploy the other factors within their borders while making trades to assist each other across borders will determine the degree of success in establishing firm and lasting peace in our time.

Best for group play.

Includes: 6 nation charts, 2 sets of cards (110 total) consisting of population, land/resources, work/technology, religion/culture, politics/military and right education, die, rules. © 2006

Board measures only 7 X 12 inches. Each army is about one-quarter inch square, with Roman numerals of I, III, V and X. Dice are about one-half inch to a side. Cards measure 1 and 1/8 X 1 and 3/4 inches.

Board and army pieces are magnetic, so you can play a game while traveling. It all folds down into a 7 X 4 X 5/8 inch wallet that actually fits into a hip pocket.

item.description:
Each player controls a small Indian tribe, made up of Hunters, Maidens, Warriors and Chiefs. The Indians want to claim as much booty as possible. So the Hunter, for example, keeps an eye out for buffalo, while the Maiden collects necklaces etc.

Players take turns revealing one of the prairie cards in the middle of the table and players may play a hand card that can claim booty placing it as quickly as possible onto the Pow-Wow board. If nobody chooses to play a hand card, then players continue to take turns revealing prairie cards until someone chooses to play a hand card, interrupting the revealing of prairie cards.
If the player plays a correct card he may claim a booty. 
If a player plays a hand card with which he could not have claimed any booty, then he must give up
the top two cards in his victory pile.

After the last prairie card has been revealed, all players have one last chance to try and claim booty.
Thereafter, the game is over. Each player counts the cards in his victory pile. The player with the most cards wins.

item.description:
From the publisher:

The game where the answer lies in the clues!

It's a race against the timer to get your team to shout out the right words... and as the timer ticks, your score goes down. Sounds easy... perhaps... except you can't speak to them. All you can do is write down five clues.

Give the right clues and maybe they'll get the right answer. But a bad clue will send them off on a wild goose chase! Tick, tick, tick, tick, BANG!

From the publisher:
Quizzit is a multiple choice quiz board game where you advance spaces by answering questions of a difficulty level of your choice. The harder the question, the more spaces you advance. Each player has a variety of Tactics Cards that can be used in your turn or theirs. If you don't know the answer then play your No Idea card. If you know the answer to someone else's question then ask them to play their Help card on you - then you both advance. The winner is the first player to get to the center of the board.

http://www.quizzit.com.au/

This game is one of the many Thomas and Friends games available in New Zealand.

This game involves moving around the board to collect passengers

The players move around a 4 by 4 board (15 tiles each with a picture of track on both sides of them and one station) from a central station following the track. The 4 x 4 grid is randomly created at the beginning of the game and the tiles can also have the 'action' or 'passengers' attribute on them as well as the track. Players move by rolling a die and moving around the tiles following the arrows and only on track that can connect, if they end on an 'action' tile then they take an action card, if they end on a 'passenger' tile then they collect 3 passengers. The next player then continues to play from the position of the last player

The action tile cards have different effects such as flipping the tiles over to the other side, making the player lose all their passengers, moving them to the bottom of the board, or cause them to end their turn.

The game continues until either a player decides to end the game, this gives the other players 2 turns to get additional passengers or the game ends when there are no more passenger cards left. In both situations the player with the most passengers wins.

The box includes 16 track maze cards, 14 action cards, 40 passengeer cards and 1 player token (which is used by all players).
"An exciting race game based on the internationally acclaimed cartoon characters who have the wonderful ability to change their shapes. Ages 5 through 9."

Challengers will outwit, out score and out match opponents to be crowned champion of this spicy new strategy game.

The object of the game is to acquire points by getting rid of all your unique triangular (tortilla chip!) cards while blocking opponents from doing the same.

Each player is dealt six cards, and a card from the deck is flipped to create a playfield. Opponents place their three-sided cards in the playfield by matching colors. There are three segments on a card, which may include colors, actions, or an unmatchable Black X. Action cards including “Skip Next”, “Opponent Draws Three”, and “Go Again." If you cannot play, you draw a card; if you match 2 or 3 sides of your card the other players draw 1 or 2 cards. The field is Closed when no plays are possible. The player Closing then deals a card to each opponent and starts a new playfield. The first player to discard all cards is awarded one point per card remaining in their opponents' hands. First player to 20 points wins.

item.description:
Educational Math board game that uses checkers type movement. The playing pieces called a "Tivit" are 6 sided dice with each side having a symbol and numerical value.

The 2 players compete by moving their tivitz across a baseball diamond towards 16 ending locations. 7 ending locations are reserved for each player and 2 are available to both.

Each ending location has a mathematical operation(addition, subtraction, multiplication or division). A players score is the value of their tivit adjusted for the math operation for each tivit that finishes the game on an ending location.

The game includes 30 different paper boards with varying degrees of difficulty along with 6 different tivitz values allowing for 180 different game setups.

For ages 8 and up.

1936 Guerra Civil (1936 civil war) is a card game in which each player plays one of the sides in the conflict, either the Republic or the Nationalists. A player must design his deck from the cards available for his side (a pool of over one hundred), with a minimum selection of 36 of them. Besides the cards belonging to one of the two sides, there are cards representing political and military objectives, for which the sides fight. Each objective gives victory points to the player who wins them. Victory can be achieved by military victory points, by political victory points, by a combination of the two of them or by the demoralization of the enemy.

The game is for two players, although some possible variants for four players are also provided.

There are different types of cards: objectives (political or military), characters, military units and management cards. Each side is made up of factions (ten factions for the Republic and eight factions for the Nationalists). A side may also benefit from having appointed a leader if certain conditions are met.

All cards have images from public Spanish archives and contain detailed historical information.

(A note on the language barrier: it's not as big as it seems. If your first language is French, Italian or Portuguese most game terms will be either the same or very similar. Even with English there are many easily understandable text parts. Additionally, all game text and rules are available to download in French and English from the game's website).

Game components:

 252 unique cards
 4 game boards (one for each side, one for managing military objectives and one for managing political objectives)
 24 small markers to be used on the boards
 1 rulebook 36 pages long, plus two additional double-side reference sheets




The game was slowly developed between 2000 and 2006 and it was finally self-published by the author himself through Ediciones Rotura as a limited and numbered edition of 1936 copies, being released in Madrid on December 29, 2006.

The game entered the BGG ranking on July 18th 2007 (anniversary of the outbreak of the war).

A small expansion ('Guernica') was released in September 2009 through Spanish magazine ALEA (#33). Several Print&Play expansions have been released since October 2009 linked to the game reaching certain milestones: number of fans in Facebook, number of distributed games, presence during gaming events.

item.description:
Based on the NBC game show of the same name.

2 Players - One is a contestant and the other is host. The contestant answers trivia questions. The host draws from the mob deck and records the contestant's winnings and mob players out on a right answer. The contestant must decide to quit or play on, because a wrong answer will cost the contestant everything. They switch roles after one game. (Note: A contestant can play up to 12 questions, even if the contestant eliminates 100 mob members.)

Multi-player - Same as above, except the following: extra players are the mob, the mob doesn't have to answer the questions, and they split the money from the contestant when the contestant gives a wrong answer. Game ends when everyone plays each role at least once.

Either way, the person with the most money wins.

Contains 400 questions, mob deck, and score pad.

This edition is out of print as of September 2008 and has been replaced by Ultimate Werewolf: Ultimate Edition

Ultimate Werewolf is a group game/activity where each of the players take on secret roles in a village that's being terrorized by werewolves. Some of the players are werewolves, many are plain, simple villagers, but many players have special abilities, such as being able to tell who is a werewolf and who isn't, and the Magician, who can save or kill any other player instantly. Each night the werewolves eat a villager. Each day, the village convenes and attempts to lynch one of their own, trying to find the werewolves that are secretly living among them.

The Ultimate Werewolf: Whitebox Edition package from Bezier Games makes this game easier to play than ever before, and supports up to 31 players! Ultimate Werewolf: Whitebox Edition includes a number of components to make your games faster, more intriguing, and more fun than ever before:

31 Sleeved Player Cards: These lavishly illustrated full-color cards contain the name of the role and a short description of that role's abilities. There's no confusion as to what each card is and what that role does. Each player card comes in a plastic sleeve with a sliding insert that covers the card face. There's no chance of accidentally flipped, dropped, or otherwise revealed cards.

Getting Started with Ultimate Werewolf Guide: This handy guide provides information and advice about everything related to setting up and moderating an Ultimate Werewolf game, from how to set up the chairs for the players to how to keep the game moving along.

Player Reference Cards: 30 full-size reference cards with a complete role listing and explanation on one side, and a detailed walk-through of the gameplay on the other.

Moderator Reference Cards: Reference cards for the Moderator with a detailed walk-through (including what to say at each step of the game) on one side, and role identity charts to fill out during the first night - never get confused over who is the hunter or any other role!

Role Suggestion Card: A handy reference card that suggests the right mix of werewolves, villagers, and special roles for players in any number from 7-31.

Name Card Tents: Included are 30 name card tents so all players can address each other by name; great for large groups, visitors, and team-building events.

The Amulet of Protection: One player secretly has an Amulet of Protection that will prevent him from dying one time. At night he may pass the Amulet to another player. Any role may have the Amulet, which is a smaller card that is inserted between the role card and the sliding insert.

Custom Cards: If you're an experienced player who likes to play with a certain role not included in the base set, you can select an additional role from a list, or even have custom cards made and enclosed with your order.

Unique custom roles found only in Ultimate Werewolf: Whitebox Edition: The Village Idiot, Wolf Cub, Aura Seer and Spellcaster.

Re-implements:

 Werewolf




Re-implemented by:

 Ultimate Werewolf: Ultimate Edition

name.value: Secret Lives of the U.S. Presidents: Trivia Card Game

item.description:
From the publisher:

We've got a big election coming up, and everyone is buzzing with talk of presidents past and future. But if you still can't tell your Tafts from your Tylers, then it s time to play Secret Lives of the U.S. Presidents: Trivia Card Game!
Complete with rules for one, two, or an entire roomful of players, this trivia card game features more than 150 witty, irreverent, and fiendishly challenging trivia questions: Which president walked his pet raccoon on a leash? Which president slept for (literally) half of the day? Who worked as a cover model for Cosmopolitan magazine? Which one blamed air pollution on trees?
Complete with hilarious two-color illustrations of every president, this trivia card game is perfect for Democrats, Republicans, and Independents of all ages. The difficulty level ranges from simple true/false answers to ultra-hard "for history geeks only" challenges. Deal out the cards -- and let the games begin!

Each player starts with a pawn, $5000 and a loan of $10,000. Then, each player must buy his or her first car. In turn, a player rolls the dice and advances one’s own pawn on the track and react to where ever the pawn lands. During the course of play a player may buy and use service stations and garages, purchase insurance, get involved in accidents, collect income and get stars, which represent safe driving awards. When a player buys a second car, that player takes two consecutive turns even though one still has only one pawn on the gameboard. A player who buys a third car may take three consecutive turns.

The path the players travel on the gameboard crosses itself twice. There is a traffic light at one intersection that regulates movement as players approach it. The traffic light changes when a player lands on one of four “red dot” spaces. This allows players approaching from the other direction to advance while stopping traffic from the first direction.

The first player to accumulate seven red stars and purchase the Cadillac Fleetwood Brougham for $10,500 is the winner.

At the beginning of the last century, in the USA some brave enterpriser's foresee the possible economic developments of the invention of the Lumière brothers and founded the first production companies. In a short time their studios became the source of dreams that every American could believe. Initially the actors came from theater, but soon the cinema started to count upon stars more and more famous, liked by the public, able to ensure the success of the movies just with their presence.

A deduction game for 2 players.
Some actors (and actresses) are dealt to both players, while the rest are kept face down on the table.
You try to guess which actors (and actresses) are in the hand of your opponent (i.e. compose her cast).
To do so, there are several actions available: each player can choose only one per turn and those not chosen are still implemented in a sort of "neutral" way (helping both players).

item.description:
Players can play individually or on teams to answer clues on cards. There are two part, three part, and four part clues. In the game, new words are created from a series of other words. The concept is best illustrated by an example, as follows:

The basic series of words:

Faucet - donkey - sapling

Is a Word-Clue for the word:

Tap - ass - tree

Tapestry

Listen to clues to guess who, what, when, where, how and why. Your team only has 1 minute to guess them all! To make it even more challenging, you must remember the words you guessed so you can write a funny Gibberish story. The better your team, the more points you earn.

The hilariously competitive guessing / memory / storytelling / beat the clock game is fun for the whole family. There are rules for a 2 or 3 player game, too, so you don't need a crowd to have a Gibberish good time!

In the year 1455, five lords are struggling for power in the middle of the Italian peninsula, and precisely in the area of the Adriatic coast:


 Sigismondo Pandolfo Malatesta, Condottiero and Lord of Rimini and Fano
 Federico II da Montefeltro, Condottiero and Lord of Urbino
 Domenico Malatesta, brother of Sigismondo. Condottiero and Lord of Cesena
 Alessandro Sforza (brother of Francesco Sforza), Lord of Pesaro
 Giacomo Piccinino, Condottiero subsidized by Alfonso d’Aragona King of Naples (who hates Sigismondo), he is trying to achieve a state for himself at the expense of Sigismondo


This ziplock-bag wargame contains:

 A 60*84 cm map, divided in areas (and not in hexagons)
 16 objectives cards
 Five counter sheets
 Two sheets of coins
 A rulebook
 Five red and five blue dice




At the third turn of the game, every player randomly pick an objective card. The first player to reach the objective written on his/her card is the winner.

L’elefante e l’aquila means “the elephant and the eagle”. The elephant was a secondary banner of the Malatesta family, and the eagle was the banner of Montefeltro family.

Rules and cards are only in Italian.

item.description:
Your cargo bays are empty. The Novo Dice dealer has the best supplies - but the lion is no typical trader. He doesn't sell his wares, he gambles for your cargo space instead.
Take the right chances and rocket fuel, robots or strange travelers are your reward.
But if you push to hard, you'll end up with the trader's space trash instead.
Novo Dice is an easy dice game
for 2-4 space adventurers 12 and up
with 15 to 30 minutes time reminiscent of a slot machine with a set collection twist.
Novo Dice was made as an advertisement gift and isn't available in retail.

This card game contains:
• 72 cards (36 with a blue back and 36 with a red back)
• A rulebook

Every card displays three numbers from 1 to 6 (vertically arranged), in six possible colors.
Players are dealt six cards each, and at their turn they can draw a new card and discard an unwanted one (discarded cards may be picked by other players). 
Goal of the game is to make winning hands, using the first, second or third line of the numbers: you can win with six numbers of the same color, or six same numbers, or a flush.

There are two variants of the game. 
• The “quick” one (named “Bussy”) has an action/dexterity factor: the player who wants a discarded card must be the fastest to grab it.
• The strategic one (named “Bussy Money”) uses poker chips and bets. And the player who wants a discarded card must bid some chips on it and win the auction. It is also possible to “bluff” a winning hand, hoping that nobody will want to see it…

The game set in Peru were ancestral stones have been found. The stones could call into question the foundations of man… or they could be a trick to gain tourist. Your archaeologist and scientist have to decide on the truth by taking their discoveries to the laboratory.

The object the game is to find different kinds of tiles and earn the most points.

This game is a free print and play game.

Home Page: http://www.neuroludic.com/ica/ica.html

You one of the first explorers to arrive on a remote planet and your job is to study it in detail. There are companies here competing against you for the most glory and power.

This is a free print and play game. There are four different planets available for download. The game rules were created in 2003.

 Was available - now is not anymore




Home Page: http://www.neuroludic.com/osmoz/osmoz.html

A Game of Money, Stocks , Shares & Wealth

This interactive game includes a 60 Min VHS Video cassette. The object of the game is to accrue as much wealth in shares and money withing 60 Minutes running time of the Boom or Bust video.

From the box:
12 gates are positioned on the board, in arbitrary sequence. Each player is issued 3 animals: one snake, one rhinoceros, and one elephant. Three of the gates are too low for any of the animals to pass under; three other gates can be passed only by the snake; another three gates are high enough to let the snake and the rhinoceros through, and three gates are high enough to allow all the animals to pass.

Players take turns rolling the dice, changing the position of the gates and advancing their animals towards the finish line.

The game is comprised of eight, ten or twelve card decks depending on which language is being presented. A deck is made up of 65 to 75 cards, with each card bearing one or more words, semi-sentences, verbs, pronouns, adjectives, etc. The phonetic pronunciation is written in the mother tongue beneath the words or sentences of the foreign language. The center of the card bears the translation of the text in your mother tongue.

The object of the game is to form complete sentences having at least a subject, a verb, and an object - and making sense. Points are awarded based on the number of cards used in creation of each phrase or sentence.

ShakeDown is a dexterity game for 2-6 players.
Your goal is to stack cards on top of a hand-held platform without them falling off.
Of course this is made a bit more difficult by the cards to be played being stored in the platform's base. So you have to move the base to get access to the cards.
All of the cards have point values which count against whomever causes them to drop.
Some of the cards also call for special actions (like "Do the twist for five seconds while holding the tower.")
And there the fun begins!

item.description:
Each player gets a number of cards that is played face down in front of them. On card is played face up in the middle of the table. At the same time everyone looks at their cards and tries to find one that has similar a element. Once you find a card with a similar element you toss it into the middle. If everyone agrees with your pick then you card becomes the start card for the next round. The first one to play all their cards wins!

The game is playable for 2-6 players but is recommended for 4 or 5. This is a free to print and play game.
Some male beetles (the players) have to fertilize the eggs that female is leaving in the ground. But the beetle-eater mouse is in the zone, and he is very hungry.

Transfer is a simple abstract 2-player game that is played on a 4x4 grid. Each player starts with 4 egg-cups, in one of two colors, on the base row of the grid, with a ball on the two corner ones. The aim is to be the first player to move these cups to the baseline of the opponent and get the 2 balls again onto the 2 egg-cups on the edges. If the starting player does this first, then the opponent has the chance to get a draw if they manage to do the same thing in the turn immediately afterwards.

Each turn a player picks one of two moves. A player can either move one cup with a ball to a free space that touches it, horizontally, vertically, or diagonally. Or a player can move the ball from one of their pieces to another one of their pieces that touches it in those same directions. When a blockade occurs, by 2 rows that block each other on the center rows, the active player may jump with a piece that contains a ball over an opponent's piece. When one player still has a piece on the start line, and the opponent has filled all other end-spaces, that piece needs to vacate its space right away. If this is impossible (when it doesn't contain a ball), then that player loses immediately.

This appears to be Dieter Hartmann's only published game.

PUBLICATION HISTORY:

 1978 Transfer Edition Perlhuhn (GÃ¶ttinger Spiele) - out of print




Like all typical Edition Perlhuhn releases, this game comes in a tube, with chunky wooden pieces (black and red) and a board that is printed on a fake leather vinyl.

ADDITIONAL INFO:

 language skill needed: language neutral.
 English translation: none. The description above should suffice.
 artwork: no artwork on the board (grid only). The label image appears to be a replication from an old scientific print. 
 awards won: none.

item.description:
This small game consists of 12 trapezoids showing 3 triangles in red, yellow and black each. The players have 2 red, 2 yellow and 2 black counters each. The object of the game is to create a winning triangle of four of one's marked counters on their appropriate colored tile areas. Players take turn laying tiles and placing counters on them or placing a counter on a tile already laid. Once all 12 counters have been played, remaining tiles are put aside. Now players may move their counters trying to form a triangle. Capturing an opponent's counter is possible by surrounding it with one's own counters.

Trox is a small print run game of high production quality.

Home Page: http://homepages.tesco.net/~peteandrew/trox.htm
